title: Source Control - Diff View Cursor Position Resets to Top of Diff Section

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Issue Type: Bug Steps: - Start editing two different files in a source controlled project - Add a large section to one of the files that spans more than one screen height - Make any change to the other file so it will appear in the source control panel - Open the source control panel and click the file with the large added section - Scroll down partway through the large add section, take note of the cursor position - Click on the other file in the source control panel - Now click back on the file with the large added section again - Observe that the cursor position will have jumped up towards the top of the add section, losing the previous cursor position Expected result: - Switching to an already open diff view for a file should not reset the cursor position - If the diff view was never closed, the last cursor position should be maintained, like any other editor tab - When a diff view is opened for the first time it should still jump to the first different section (as it already does) Motivation: Using the Source Control panel with "Toggle Side by Side View" off as a replacement for the Explorer panel as a workflow for focusing on currently modified files only. The cursor position being reset when switching back and forth between files diff views is disruptive to this workflow. VS Code version: Code 1.31.1 (1b8e8302e405050205e69b59abb3559592bb9e60, 2019-02-12T02:16:38.656Z) OS version: Darwin x64 18.2.0

title: Allow to run extension tests through typescript files
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
We currently use Mocha to run all of our tests through the out/ folder within our repository. We want to switch to using ts-node in conjunction with mocha so that we can run the tests and collect coverage information (with NYC) through the typescript files, rather than compiled javscript. This works fine for unit tests, but it doesn't seem to work with vscode-integration tests. I believe due to the way the extension development host is launched, it is looking specifically for a javascript extension so can't interpret our typescript files. 
Is it possible to change that so that we are able to also run vscode-integration tests through the typescript files? Thanks!

title: Terminal shows corrupt texture sometimes when resuming the OS from a sleep state

milestone.title: On Deck

Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body: **Workaround:** Press ctrl++ and ctrl+- (mac: cmd++, cmd+-) to zoom VS Code in and out which will do a complete redraw of the terminal. --- Repro: 1. Open a terminal, run some commands 2. Sleep system 3. Resume the system (I think the delay between 2 and 3 has to be a while) What happens exactly differs across machines, I've seen full black, full transparent and things like this: It seems like both the main terminal canvas texture as well as the texture atlas textures can become corrupted.

title: Files served by readonly filesystem initially lack the '(read-only)' suffix on tab labels

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1 and 1.32.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.16299

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Obtain the MemFS sample (git clone https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-extension-samples and then go to the fsprovider-sample subdir)
2. Edit package.json to require a newer version of vscode than the sample's default. I changed ```"vscode": "^1.23.0"``` to ```"vscode": "^1.31.0"```. This is necessary in order to get use of the isReadonly option on ```vscode.workspace.registerFileSystemProvider```
3. ```npm install``` in Terminal
4. Edit src/extension.ts to add that ```isReadonly: true``` to the options parameter.
5. F5
6. When Extension Development Host window opens, switch to it, press F1 and run 'MemFS: Setup Workspace', then F1 again and 'MemFS: Create Files'.
7. Switch to Explorer view.
8. Single-click on one of the files, e.g. file.js and observe that the tab caption lacks the '(read-only)' suffix.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6726799/53635715-e24a2300-3c15-11e9-9b1d-80fc8c0f0f76.png)

9. Try typing into the document and verify it is correctly read-only.
10. Doubleclick on the tab to persist it. The caption now gets the expected '(read-only)' suffix.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6726799/53636076-eb87bf80-3c16-11e9-9281-69fe2c2fa026.png)

Also notice the weird doubled-up '(read-only) (read-only)' on  the titlebar. Is this intentional?

title: Search for files should prefer findings in one piece
body:
Hi,

I press `CTLR + P` to find files. I'm looking for a file `index.cfm` in a folder `sap`
In the results list I see many files in folders that contain the characters `s`, `a` and `p` anywhere distributed in that string in that order.
The file in the one folder that's an exact match is only to be found after I scroll towards the bottom.

In my screen you see the bottom entry. The first `s` found in the path is highlighted,
I would love to see that code gives a high priority to files whose name or path contain the search string as entered by the user.
![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/802702/53634376-58e91f80-3c1a-11e9-84f6-37eced2f20bc.png)

title: Show an obvious indicator that an updated extension requires a reload

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
When an extension has auto-updated it displays a reload required notice on the extension inside the extensions view. 

This is only noticeable if you open the extensions view and on long running vscode sessions a user may not realise they should reload. This can result in users filing duplicate and/or previously resolved error reports on the extension repo. Could a more obvious notification be shown?

![screenshot from 2019-03-01 09-18-51](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5885195/53602499-1c5df980-3c03-11e9-942e-0a976031334b.png)

title: Relaunch Workspaces After Windows Restart for Updates

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
# Summary
This pull request implements a lightweight service that registers Visual Studio Code for application restart in Windows. This is only observed when the system reboots itself; usually for a Windows update.

[Example Here](https://i.imgur.com/0WUn4oA.gifv)

Resolves #12630 

### Testing
1. Run `yarn gulp vscode-win32-x64` to package the application
1. Navigate to the package output (`..\VSCode-win32-x64`)
1. Run `Code - OSS.exe`
1. Run `shutdown /g /t 0` to simulate a restart from Windows update.

This will only properly work from a packaged version of Visual Studio Code. Having a virtual machine to test in is also useful.

### Changes
In order to use the [`RegisterApplicationRestart`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/api/winbase/nf-winbase-registerapplicationrestart) method, I had to create a [Node.js extension](https://github.com/kdelorey/node-windows-register-restart) for the method. I'm happy to transfer ownership of the extension to the Microsoft GitHub organization if required.

A service was then added that handles the registration of Visual Studio Code for restart. It also hooks into one of the opened code windows to listen for `WM_ENDSESSION`. The `WM_ENDSESSION` is triggered before a shutdown. I use this opportunity to ask the `LifecycleService` to `quit(fromUpdate: true)`. I use the `fromUpdate` argument in order to save all of the opened workspaces into the `storage.json` file.

title: Coursor moves lines during scroll
body:
_From @zubr1 on February 26, 2019 22:27_

I encountered a frustrating problem after few minutes of my first experience with VS Code. When I scroll up or down through the code, the cursor follows me. That's a nice feature which I didn't notice previously in VS. So fast two fingers swipe on laptop touchbar, makes the cursor scrolling, until it reaches satisfying position (it takes about 1s). The point is that if during the cursor scrolling, we want to switch to another view (for instance web browser) by very popular ALT+TAB shortcut, the cursor (which is still scrolling) catches ALT, and activates ALT+UP/DOWN hotkey. As a result it unexpectedly moves line of code up or down. 
It's really uncomfortable, because we have to wait until the cursor did not stop.

![vscode_error](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11910368/53450050-9d5a9c80-3a1b-11e9-93f7-4381a3f96571.gif)


_Copied from original issue: OmniSharp/omnisharp-vscode#2875_

title: VSCode shouldn't allow extensions to disable TLS
body:
I'm not sure how hard it would be to prevent extensions from doing this, but recently [it was found that a particularly popular extension had set `NODE_TLS_REJECT_UNAUTHORIZED` to 0](https://github.com/shanalikhan/code-settings-sync/issues/776), which – to my understanding – causes any editor with that extension installed to allow any HTTPS connections regardless of whether their TLS certificate is valid.

I'd argue that extensions should never be allowed to do this. Though there may be certain edge cases where this'd be necessary, it almost definitely isn't worth the risk to the average user.

I'm not a security professional, but I couldn't find any existing issues on the topic so I felt like I needed to open this.

Thanks for the great editor!

title: Extension api: WorkspaceSymbolProvider.resolveWorkspaceSymbol is never called without working around the type system
body:
Version: 1.32.0-insider
Commit: ce073b0076ac2f69faf2c609af72f9b81506c791
Date: 2019-02-27T06:15:35.767Z
Electron: 3.1.3
Chrome: 66.0.3359.181
Node.js: 10.2.0
V8: 6.6.346.32
OS: Darwin x64 18.2.0

Docs for [WorkspaceSymbolProvider](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#WorkspaceSymbolProvider).provideWorkspaceSymbols state that:

> To improve performance implementors can implement resolveWorkspaceSymbol and then provide symbols with partial location-objects, without a range defined. The editor will then call resolveWorkspaceSymbol for selected symbols only.

Unfortunately, there is no type-safe way of creating Location objects with an undefined Range. 
 Using Range or Position in the only constructor`constructor(uri: Uri, rangeOrPosition: Range | Position);` results in `resolveWorkspaceSymbol` never being called.

If you hack around the type system, you can get around this constraint. e.g. `undefined as any` as the constructor arg, or `(location as any).range = undefined;` after construction.  Once you do this, `resolveWorkspaceSymbol` is called as expected. 

So the logic does work, it's just awkward to get there without battling the type system.

Thanks!

title: An option to manually set indent size in an editor
body:
As a motivating example, consider the following source file:
```python
import textwrap

def main():
    print(textwrap.dedent('''\
    <!DOCTYPE HTML>
    <html>
      <head>
        <title>hello world</title>
      </head>
      <body>
        Hello, world!
      </body>
    </html>'''))

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```

On one hand, it's Python code, so I want indent 4. On another, it's HTML and I want indent 2. Generally, I want to manually change indent size depending on what I'm editing at the moment.

When I click on the indentation indicator in the status bar, the following actions are offered:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/302938/53472211-18ea3700-3a78-11e9-974a-b7aecd69a9a1.png)

It would be nice to also have a "Set indent size to a specified number" action.

title: Find with Selection steals keyboard focus
body:
The "Find with Selection" command (which defaults to Command-E on Mac) opens the find panel and moves keyboard focus to the find panel's text field.

This is an operating system wide command on Macs and it should behave exactly the same as doing a "Copy" operation in copy/paste. Specifically:

1. It should not open the find panel or any other interface.
2. It should not move keyboard focus away from the text editing area.

Personally I'd be happy if just item 2 was resolved, but really they should both be fixed.

title: If you can't upgrade an extension, tell why!
body:
Now I know that if I can't install latest version of an extension, it may be because I don't run the latest version on VScode. I learned it [the hard way](https://github.com/eamodio/vscode-gitlens/issues/666), because  it was not obvious and didn't understand why VScode didn't offer to update GitLens from 8.54 to 9.51 on VScode v1.2.1

- Please, in the marketplace, in the header of each extension could you indicate the VScode version needed to install it's latest version.
- When installing an extension, could you alert the user when there is a newer version of the extension that requires a more recent version of VScode.

title: "Smart" output scroll lock is too sticky

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

body:
- VSCode Version: 1.31.1
- OS Version: 10.14.2

![vsc](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/50314/53442574-9742cc80-39d7-11e9-8283-251b8de77c59.gif)

Steps:

1. Make sure "scroll lock" is turned _off_ in the Output panel.
2. Run your project's test suite inside VSCode, e.g. run Go tests.
3. Click somewhere in the Output panel. This automatically enables the smart scroll lock.
4. Run your project's test suite again. **Scroll lock is still on and prevents the output from being "followed"**.

From where I'm sitting, it looks like the "smart" scroll lock becomes stuck and doesn't unstick when the terminal screen is cleared for a new run.

[This issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/49110) causes the above unexpected and undesired behaviour. 

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes
